moves.1. c4 e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. cxd5:
A large number of people play this move.
Alternative variation: 3. d4 [is best here, I think.] 
Alternative variation: 3. g3 [playable.] 
Alternative variation: 3. b3 [also playable here.]
moves.3... exd5 4. d4 Nf6 5. a3: Alternative variation: 5. Nc3 [should be considered here.]
moves.5... Bd6 6. Nc3 c6 7. Bg5 O-O 8. e3 Bg4: Getting the Bishop out before my Knight. I want to play Nbd7.
moves.9. Be2 Nbd7 10. O-O h6 11. Bh4 Re8 12. R: Here I had a number things, or fantasy positions, I wanted to go for. I wanted to unpin my Knight , so a Queen move here is what I was looking at here.
moves.12... Qc7:
This was move I had chosen.
Alternative variation: 12... Qb6 [This is the move I looked at more than any other, I wonder why I didn't play it.] 13. Qc2 g5 14. Bg3 Bxg3 15. hxg3 Bh5 [Heading to g6.]
moves.13. Bg3 Bxg3 14. hxg3: Wow! I was planning to double the pawns, but my opponent has done that for me. This is the only advantage I had in the game for the next 15 or 20 moves. My pawns are better here, This is what Karpov and Capablanca would call a long term strategic advantage.
moves.14... Ne4 15. Qc2: Alternative variation: 15. Nxe4 Rxe4 [Followed by Nf6 or Rad8 or Qb6 to attack the b pawn.]  (15... dxe4 16. Nd2 Bxe2 17. Qxe2 Nf6)
moves.15... Nxc3 16. Qxc3 Bxf3 17. Bxf3 Nf6 18: Now I don't to lose a tempo with f2-f3.
moves.21. b5 Rc8 22. a4 a6: I don't know how if this was a good move or not. It just seems right to play, so I did.
moves.23. bxa6: Alternative variation: 23. bxc6 Rxc6 (23... Qxc6 24. Qxc6 Rexc6 (24... bxc6 25. Rc3 Kf8 26. Rec1 (26. Rb1 a5 27. Rb6 c5 28. Rxe6 fxe6 29. dxc5 Rc6 [My opponent has two pawn island to my three, but I still think I have an advantage here.] ) ) 25. Rxc6 Rxc6 26. Rb1 Rc7 (26... b6 [Not sure if this wolud be a good move or not. ] ) ) 24. Qb2 Rxc1 25. Rxc1 Qd7 26. Rxc8+ (26. a5 Rxc1+ 27. Qxc1 Qb5 28. Qc8+ Kh7 29. Qc7 f6) 26... Qxc8 27. Qb3 Qc6 [Standoff.]
moves.23... bxa6 24. Rcb1 c5: I wasn't planning on this move, but when Rb1 was played, I wanted to strke for the soon to be open c-file. I didn't plan on using the b-file at all, I just wanted to protect c6.
moves.25. Qxc5 Qxc5 26. dxc5 Rxc5 27. Rb4 a5: Alternative variation: 27... Re4 28. Rb6 (28. Rxe4 dxe4 29. Rd1 (29. Rb1 Rc4 30. Ra1 a5) 29... a5 30. Rd4 Re5 31. f4 exf3 32. gxf3 Rxe3) 28... Rxa4 29. Rb8+ Kh7 30. Reb1
moves.28. Rd4 Re4 29. Red1 Rxd4 30. Rxd4 Rc4: Alternative variation: 30... Rc1+ 31. Kh2 Rc4 [This was also a thought.]
moves.31. Rxc4: Alternative variation: 31. Rxd5 Rxa4 [The only problem here is that the Rook is in front of the passed pawn and not behind it.] 32. Rd8+ Kh7 33. Rd7 ( 33. Ra8 Kg6 34. Ra6+ f6) 33... Kg6 34. Ra7
moves.31... dxc4 32. Kf1: Here I had to count to see if my King would get to the c pawn in time.
moves.32... Kf8 33. Ke2 Ke7 34. Kd2 Kd6 35. Kc: Now that the passed pawn is protected, how can I put White into Zugzwang.
moves.36. f4 f5: This move jump out at me like a lighting bolt, but not there yet.
moves.37. g4 g6 38. gxf5: Alternative variation: 38. g3 h5 39. gxh5 (39. gxf5 gxf5)  39... gxh5
moves.40. e4 fxe4 41. f5 e3 42. f6 Kd6 43. Kc2: Alternative variation: 43... Ke6 [The winning move for me.]

moves.62. Qa8+: Alternative variation: 62. Qe5 Kb3 [Winning move for my opponent, as pionted out in the chat by another playerafter the game. Wow! Only I can turn a win into a lose. Oh well, that's chess.] 63. Qh8 Kc2 64. Qa1 Kb3 65. Kg4 [Bringing the King over to help and the game will be over shortly.]
moves.66. Qa4+ Kb2 67. Qb4+ Ka1: Keeping the King in the corner as much as possible.
Draw better than a lose. I let one get away...again. The truth is, we BOTH let that one get away, but I had the win first.
